text: last week at Reading University in the
UK eugene goostman accomplished
something very controversial he passed
the Turing test at an event hosted by
the Royal Society of London goostman
which was actually a computer program
that claimed to be a thirteen-year-old
Ukrainian boy fooled 10 out of 30 judges
in the thinking that he was human after
chatting with each one of them one on
one for 5 minutes he's doing so he
passed the famous Turing test as
described by the code-breaking computer
genius Alan Turing in 1950 now a lot of
people have jumped on the claim arguing
that Turing had meant for the test to be
a lot harder than that and if you're one
of those people let me quote you chapter
inverse in his 1950 paper Computing
Machinery and intelligence Turing
proposed a computer program that could
imitate human conversation well enough
that and I quote an average interrogator
will not have more than 70% chance of
making the right identification after
five minutes of questioning in other
words if it could hold up a conversation
well enough for five minutes that one in
three people would think that they were
talking to a human being and like it or
not goostman did do that the program was
created by vladimir vilasa and eugene
demchenko who have been entering
goostman into various turn competitions
into fine-tuning it for years but
gooseman
isn't a super intelligent computer or
anything it's just a program that could
probably run on your laptop you can even
talk to a version of gooseman
online but don't expect to be blown away
by some great leap forward in computer
evolution what is that a lot of people
angry is that honestly the program
relies pretty heavily on the fact that
there are a lot of actual human 13-year
old boys who would have a hard time
convincing you that they were human it
tells dirty jokes it hits on women it
ignores your questions and it likes to
launch into bizarre poorly thought-out
rants about video games and politics
whatever it sees an opportunity you can
try to get it to demonstrate practical
logic or abstract thinking by asking you
questions like can you push a car with a
piece of string but it'll probably just
make fun of you for asking stupid
questions and then ask you if you have a
cute sister
so was the Turing test passed yeah does
it
not really it will still be a long time
before we're talking to computer
programs that really sound like people
at least people other than obnoxious
little brothers now do you remember the
last time you were watching TV or a
movie or dumb Dan down tumblr and all of
a sudden you see something that really
grosses you out you probably do because
according to a study published in this
week's Journal of communication we
remember the things that disgust us
better than just about anything else
doctors bridgett ruben king of the
university of florida and annie lange of
Indiana University conducted an
experiment with 120 participants in
order to measure the effects of getting
grossed out they exposed their
participants to a wide variety of kinds
of disgusting video from severe bodily
trauma resulting in death to a neo-nazi
spewing hate speech to a man going
number two on a filthy bathroom floor ah
by the way sounds like the least fun
experiment to be a part of ever they
jacked a number of different measures of
disgusted response including emotional
responses changes in heart rate
fluctuations in skin conductivity and
activation of the levator lady II that's
the muscle at the top of your lift that
makes you go like that
then there's your oral rejection system
which is just the scientific way of
saying the thing that makes you gag and
one of you we've all got to keep
contaminates out of our body so it makes
sense that imagery involving dead people
and feces trigger that response you
don't want to breathe in that stuff you
definitely don't want it in you and over
time we evolved to link that disgusted
reaction to sources of social and moral
disgust as well things like racism and
child abuse what Ruben Qing and Lange
discovered is that while the initial
reaction of moral disgust is slower than
the reaction to seeing somebody get cut
in half moral disgust increased with
repeated exposure but the core disgusts
like the disgust for bodily trauma and
secretions actually became less potent
over time the researchers say their
findings have important implications for
media clinical psychology even
advertising because no matter how
uninterested you are and what's on TV
you will pay attention when you see
something that disgusts you and you'll
remember that thing that you see it's
appears to be an evolved allocation of
mental resources to make sure that the
next time you see that super gross thing
you're really super far away from it
